entry.et: among from Middle English, from Old English on gemonge, from on + gemonge, dative of gemong crowd, from ge- (associative prefix) + -mong (akin to Old English mengan to mix); amongst from Middle English amonges, from among + -es -s co-, mingle

def.dt: :in or through the midst of :surrounded by hidden among the trees
:in company or association with living among artists
:by or through the aggregate of discontent among the poor
:in the number or class of wittiest among poets among other things she was president of her college class
:in shares to each of divided among the heirs
:through the reciprocal acts of quarrel among themselves
:through the joint action of made a fortune among themselves
